titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.27 (28 June-5 July 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 27. Mercurius Publicus: COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence; WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. From Thur≈øday June 28. to Thur≈øday July 5. 1660.
To the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent MAJESTY.
The humble Petition of the Nobility and Gentry of the Six Counties of North-wales.
div.p:
THat your Petitioners being fully a≈ø≈øured of the dutiful affections of their Neighbours and Country-men of the Briti≈øh Nation in the Six Counties afore≈øaid, do in all humility and thankfulne≈øs to God and your Maje≈øty, on behalf of our ≈øelves and them, acknowledge tho≈øe happy
fruits of your Maje≈øties mo≈øt Gracious Government whereof we have already ta≈øted, in that ≈øecurity and freedome we enjoy in the liberty of our per≈øons and property of our E≈øtates.

And though we cannot make the lea≈øt doubt (being convinced thereunto by your Maje≈øties mo≈øt pious and exemplary practice in matters of Religion) but that your Maje≈øties fir≈øt and chief care is for the re≈øettlement of the Church upon the Ancient Foundation of Truth and Peace; yet ≈øeeing we have ≈øuffered ≈øo deeply in the contrary practice by ≈øome that of late have had he power over us, who under the pretence of propagating the Go≈øpel, have for a long time ≈øhut up our Churches, converted the endowman ‚Ä¢ s of the Church to their own u≈øe, and ≈øown the ≈øeeds of fal≈øe Doctrine and Schi≈øm among us.

p.hi: Your Maje≈øties Petitioners think them≈øelves in duty bound, to repre≈øent in all humility this grievance to your Sacred Maje≈øty, and as the be≈øt expedient for the re-obtaining their form ‚Ä¢ r happine≈øs in order to their eternal Salvation (without which nothing can be happy to them) to be≈øeech your Maje≈øty, that out of your pious and Princely care, you would be plea≈øed to cau≈øe all tho≈øe good and whole≈øome Laws for uniformity in Religion, the Government of the Church, and the maintenance of the Clergy, to be put in execution, which have been made ≈øince the Reformation, whether by your Royal, Pre ‚Ä¢ ece≈øsor, Queen Elizabeth, or your Grandfather, and Father of ever happy memory.

closer.signed: And your Petitioners ≈øhall pray, &c. Sub≈øcribed by Herbert, H. Herbert, John Salisbury, Thomas Middleton, Thomas Humphreys, and ≈øeveral other Gentlemen of Quality.

div.p: By Letters from Edinborough of the 21, we have this further accompt of the ≈øolemnity, That the Major General, after his remembrance of h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Maje≈øty to the Earl of Scaford, fired the great Cannon called Mounce Megg (a Cannon never fired but on extraordinary occa≈øions) after which followed all the Guns in Edinborough Ca≈øtle, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Cittadel, and the ≈øhips in the Road. A plentiful Large≈øs was be≈øtowed among≈øt the Souldiery to heighten them in their joye ‚Ä¢ ; about fifteen hundred bonfires were ma ‚Ä¢ e on Arthurs Seat, one or forty load of coals, and at the Major Generals door one almo≈øt as big. After this was variety of fire-works, ≈øome burned in the water, other fl ‚Ä¢ w in the ayr, two Ca≈øtles firing one again≈øt the other, then ≈øeveral ≈øorts of boxes thrown into the ayr, and falling in ≈øeveral ≈øhapes, which with divers others, gave great content to the ≈øpectators

My Corre≈øpondent there did further inform me, that what he vvrit concerning Major Ahernthey, vvas too greedily taken up by him from ‚Ä¢ brisk report that vvas rai≈øed by ≈øome ill people, and de≈øires it may be amended in the next P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nt, vvhich for his and the Readers ≈øatisfaction I have done accordingly. As for Major Aberlu, my friend of the Intelligence Office, hath not yet told me vvhere he lives, till which time I mu≈øt de≈øire that Gentlemans pardon.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p:
On Thur≈øday, being the day appointed for the Thank≈øgiving for his ≈øacred Maje≈øties re≈øtauration in his Maje≈øties pa≈ø≈øage ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ween the Guard-chamber, and his clo≈øet, ≈øtood a per≈øon nee ‚Ä¢ up „Äà‚óä„Äâ will w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h a drawn ≈øword under his cloak, which was not „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ di≈øcover ‚Ä¢ ; „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ M ‚Ä¢ je≈øty pa≈ø≈øing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
George „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Se ‚Ä¢ jeant at A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, ca≈øting ‚Ä¢ is eye about for the ≈øecurity of his M ‚Ä¢ je≈øties „Äà‚óä„Äâ , di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ overed the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Sword, and thereupon pre≈øently with his Mace ≈øeized „Äà‚óä„Äâ the per≈øon ‚Ä¢ ook from „Äà‚óä„Äâ the ≈øaid naked ≈øword, and upon view found the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢ to be a „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øword back ‚Ä¢ ilted, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ked half way down from the point, a weapon ‚Ä¢ it „Äà‚óä„Äâ a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , but by the care and p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ denc ‚Ä¢ of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , his Maje≈øties „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ mi≈øchief was prevented, the per≈øon ≈øecured, and his Maj ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ by a Right Honorable the Earl of Pemoroke, and the party remains under examination.

Friday. His Maje≈øty with his two Royal Brothers, the Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter, with ≈øeveral of the Nobility and Gentry, went to Copt-hall, where they were highly treated by the Earl of Middle≈øex.
On Saturday his Maje≈øty, with their Royal Highne≈ø≈øes his Brothers, his Excellency, with divers of the Nobility and Gentry, were highly entertained at Roehampton.

div.head: From his Excellencies Quarters at the Cock-pit.
div.p: On Monday his Excellency granted a Commi≈ø≈øion to Major Richard Fincher, to be Major to Col. Nortons Regiment at Port≈ømouth. Al≈øo a Commi≈ø≈øion to Captain Potts, ≈øon to Sir John Potts, to be a Captain in the ≈øame Regiment.
Sir John Mennes having a Patent from his Maje≈øty to be Governour of D ‚Ä¢ al Ca≈øtle, his Excellency ordered the pre≈øent Governour forthwith to ≈øurrender it to him.
William Bing E≈øq hauing a Patent for Weymouth Ca≈øtle, his Excellency ordered the pre≈øent Governour forthwith to ≈øurrender it to him.

His Excellency hath by Commi≈ø≈øion given the Command of the Regiment which was lately Col. Hackers, to Francis Lord Hawley, Vi≈øcount Duncannon. He hath likewi≈øe given a Commi≈ø≈øion to Sir Chiche≈øter Wrey, to be Major of that Regiment, to Sir Francis Vincent Baronet, Sir Thomas Stukeley, James Muldiford, and _____
Sherrard, to be Captains in the ≈øame Regiment.
On Friday his Excellency ≈øate in the Hou≈øe of Commons, and took his leave of them, having ≈øuch Honours conferred on him by his Maje≈øty, as puts him in an higher capacity.

Major Abr. Holmes, Timothy Clare, Nicholas Lockyer, R. Jones, Anth. Spinage, and _____
Gregory Captains, Commi≈ø≈øary Everard, Lievt. Hendly, Lievtenant Goff, and one Corporal Brown, formerly committed to the cu≈øtody of the Mar≈øhal General, and being no Officers in this pre≈øent Army, were on Saturday by his Excellencies Order di≈øcharged of their Impri≈øonment, upon giving ≈øecurity to be true and loyal Subjects to our Soveraign Lord the King, and not to di≈øturb the publick peace of his Maje≈øties Kingdomes.

div.head: London.
div.p: The Artillery Company meeting on Tue≈øday the 26 of June, 1660. at a general Court then held in the Artillery garden did unanimou≈øly make choice of his Highne≈øs the Duke of York to be their Commander in chief, and made choice of twelve of the Court of A ‚Ä¢ ≈øi≈øtants, to acquaint his Highne≈øs the ewith, and de≈øire his acceptance. On Saturday the 30th of June, the Lord Lucas, Sir John Robin≈øon, Lievtenant of the Tower, their Deputy Pre≈øident, with Col. Shepherd, and others of the A≈ø≈øi≈øtants accordingly, went to Whitehall, to attend his Highne≈øs, and being commanded by him to come into his Bed cha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , the L. Lucas acquainted the Duke that the≈øe Gentlemen of the Artillery Company were come to tender their ≈øervices unto his Highne≈øs, and to acquaint him what they had done in reference to his Election to be their Commander in chief; then Col Shepherd was de≈øired to declare the mind of the Company, which he did in the≈øe words following:

body.p:
WE are commanded by the Artillery Company to acquaint you, that at our General Court your Highne≈øs was with one heart and one hand freely cho≈øen to be our Commander in chief; but we dur≈øt not have ≈øo pre≈øumed, had we not known that your Highne≈øs was a Lover of Arms in general, and that in the year 1641. You manife≈øted ≈øo much love to that Company in particular, that you honored us ≈øo far, as
to enter your ≈øelf to be a member of it; and it being the ancient cu≈øtome of our Company ≈øtill to have liberty to make choice of one of the members of it to be our Commander, we do humbly pray your Highne≈øs will pardon our boldne≈øs, and be plea≈øed to own us as your own Company, and to accept of our earne≈øt reque≈øt to be our Commander in chief, and we ≈øhall be ready to yeild obedience to your Highne≈øs Commands.

closer.signed: And humbly pray for the encrea≈øe of your Highne≈øs pro≈øperity and happine≈øs.

div.p: Upon which motion his Highne≈øs did very lovingly accept of it, and them, and promi≈øed they ≈øhould ≈øtill continue their ancient priviledges and cu≈øtomes, and he would be ready to do what he could for them: Then he asked what number they might be; it was an≈øwered, about four hundred or five hundred, and that they hoped they ≈øhould be above three hundred in Arms on Thur≈øday next to attend him, and if they were commanded, ≈øhould be ready to wait upon him that very day at Whitehall; and when the Company was drawn up, they ≈øhould deliver unto him their leading ≈øt ‚Ä¢ ff, according to cu≈øtome: To which he replyed, He would accept of it, and returned them hearty thanks.

On Friday the 29th, a Committee of Aldermen and Common-Council went to invite the Lords of his Maje≈øties Privy-Council to dinner with them at Guild-hall, July 5. the day appointed by his Maje≈øty, which they were plea≈øed to accept of: They likewi≈øe made a particular invitation to the Lord Chancellor, and ≈øeveral other per≈øons of Honor, which they were plea≈øed to accept. His Sacred Maje≈øty in con≈øideration of the eminent ≈øervices and con≈øtant loyalty of Sir John Robin≈øon Knight and Baronet, Alderman of London, made him Lievtenant of the Tower, which on Friday he took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of.
To morrow Doctor Reynolds is to preach before his Maje≈øty in his Chappel at Whitehall.

We have received a confirmation of the taking of the Ca≈øtle of Schiatto, by Gen. Moro≈øini, who hath given leave to 300 Turks, that were there in Garri≈øon, to go out with their Families, and gave to the Aga that commanded them, a Ve≈ø≈øel to tran≈øport him≈øelf to the next Continent. After which exploit he went to the I≈øle of Cerigo with his Army. M. Marco B ‚Ä¢ mb ‚Ä¢ , General of Candia, hath ≈øent word hither, that the Turks having drawn their Forces within a Pi≈øtol ≈øhot off the Out-works of the Metropolitan City of that I≈øland, they found there ≈øuch re≈øi≈øtance, that they were forced to retire with great precipitation and lo≈øs of men: And that they were expecting with great impatience the ≈øupplies of the Chri≈øtian Princes, to recruite their Souldiers, above 900 of theirs being lately dead of ≈øeveral di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: St. John de Laz, Iune 21. 1660.
div.p: The 12 in≈øtant, the Count of Fuen≈øeldagne, Extraordinary Emba≈ø≈øadour of Spain, having been met at Aurogna by the Mar≈øhal de Cl ‚Ä¢ remb ‚Ä¢ ut and M. de Chabenas, Bonnevil Introductor of the Emba≈ø≈øadours, who went to fetch him with the Kings Coaches, followed by the Coaches of all the Lords of the Court, made his entrance into this Town with a magnificent Retinue, as you have heard already. He was conducted to the Lodgings prepared for him, and pre≈øently after v ‚Ä¢ ≈øited by the Duke of Crequi, in the name of the King; by M. de St. Ange for the Queen Mother, by the Marquis of H ‚Ä¢ utefort for the Queen, by the Count of Va ‚Ä¢ llac for Mon≈øieur the Kings Brother, and by the Abbot of Par ‚Ä¢ bere for the Cardinal Mazarin. Then the Count of Armagnac, great ma≈øter of the Hor≈øe, with the ≈øaid M. de Bonnevil, went to fetch him with the Kings Coaches and brought him to his audience. That night the Cardinal M ‚Ä¢ zarin fea≈øted him at Supper, and the King gave him the plea≈øure of a Spani≈øh Comedy. The 13. the two Queens made their Devotions at the Church of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ . The ≈øame day Cardinal Mazarin met again with Don Lewis d' Aro at the I≈øle of the Conference. The 14. then Maje≈øties went to take the air upon the Sea≈øide, and the 15 the whole Court went away from hence for Bayonne.

div.head: Bayonne, Iune 22. 1660.
div.p:
The 15 in≈øtant, the Queen made her entrance here with all „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . The King, Mon≈øieur his Brother and the Queen Mother came fir≈øt into this C ‚Ä¢ ty. The Prince≈øs arrived here in a very rich Coach, being accompanied by t ‚Ä¢ e Prince≈øs Palatin ‚Ä¢ , and the Dutche≈øs of N ‚Ä¢ v ‚Ä¢ illes. There w ‚Ä¢ nt before her „Äà‚óä„Äâ , all the other Coaches for her hou≈øhold, with ≈øix Trumpets of the Kings, four of the
Chamber, and two others, at the head of the Gensd' armes and the Light Hor≈øemen. The Kings Life-guard was about her Coach, and the Queen Mothers Guards, and the Company of Musketeers on Hor≈øe back were at the Rear. When ≈øhe came to a Triumphant Arch erected out of the Gates, with a rich Canopy of red Damask ≈øpread with Golden Flowers de Luce, ≈øhe alighted, and a≈øcended the Throne prepared there, where being under the Canopy, with the Crown on her Head, the Duke of E≈øpernon, Governour of this Province, who was come hither purpo≈øely to receive her Maje≈øty in this fir≈øt City both of his Governmenment and of the Kingdom, pre≈øented to her the Officers of the Senechal and the Jurat ‚Ä¢ , who made their Speeches to her Maje≈øty; which done, he pre≈øented to her Maje≈øty, in a Bi≈øon, the Keyes of the City. Then coming down from her Throne, ≈øhe was conducted by four Con≈øuls under another Canopy of Cloth of Gold and Silver to her Coach. She continued her Journey, two U≈øhers of the Chambers going before her with the Maces, the four Con≈øuls carrying the Canopy, and all the Corporations of this City in their Formalities; At the ≈øounding of the Trumpets her Maje≈øty came into the Town, through the ≈øtreets hung with rich Hangings, and ≈øtrewed wi ‚Ä¢ h Flowers, and went to the Cathedral Church, the Avenues whereof were lined by two Files of the Company of the 100 Switzers. Her Maje≈øty went in under the Canopy, and was received by our Bi≈øhop and his Clergy with his u≈øual Ceremonies, who conducted her to the great Altar, where the Te Deum was ≈øung.

From thence her Maje≈øty went to the Kings Lodgings through ≈øome ≈øtreets richly adorned, and lined with M ‚Ä¢ squ ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce ‚Ä¢ es, Gen ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ rms, and Light-Hor≈øemen. At night the Ceremony was ended by Bonfires lighted every where, with an infinite number of Lights at the Windows, continual ≈øhooting of the Canons, and the Inhabitants Mu≈økets,
by the reiterated acclamations of the people high and low, and by all other tokens of an extraordinary joy, befitting the fir≈øt City of the Kingdom that had the honour to receive a Prince≈øs, to whom the Nation is engaged for its tranquillity. The next day their Maje≈øties went to Ma≈øs to the ≈øame Church; and having again received the Complements of our Con≈øuls, they went that night to Aqs. The Count de Fuen≈øeldagn hath bin fea≈øted at B ‚Ä¢ dache by Mar≈øhal Duke de Grammont, with his ordinary ≈øumptuou≈øne≈øs and neatne≈øs; which hath given great ≈øatisfaction to the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øadour, who could not but admire the beauty and richne≈øs of that Hou≈øe, where nothing is wanting that can contribute to the ornament of a Hou≈øe of plea≈øure.

The 21 in≈øtant, the Royal Prince≈øs having been entertained with rich Pre≈øents by the Chamber of the Ea≈øt-India Company, went away from hence towards Harlem. The affairs of the Prince her Son go on very well in our Provinces, the States of Zealand having appointed Commi≈ø≈øioners to draw a Li≈øt of the charges and places formerly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his Predece≈ø≈øors, and ≈øettle all things again as they were in 1651.

Their Maje≈øties being come from Bayonne to Aqs, came on the 10 to B ‚Ä¢ zas, and the next day arrived here. This Town vvas prepared to receive them with a greater ≈øolemnity then vvas performed, becau≈øe the King would not ≈øuffer it, having bin plea≈øed to accept of our re≈øpects, expre≈ø≈øed to their Maje≈øties by the ≈øpeeches of the Corporations of Ju≈øtice, and of the Town, and of our affection te≈øt ‚Ä¢ fied unto them by the great and joyful acclamations of all ou ‚Ä¢ people. The 20. their Maje≈øties went from hence for Burdeaux.

The 21 in≈øtant about three a clock in the morning there was a great Earthquake here, which did much affright us. We hear that the like hapned at the ≈øame time at Bourdeaux, Montpellier, Beziers and other places. Mr. de Merenville hath given order for drawing, with all po≈ø≈øible diligence out of Ro≈øes and Cap de Quiers, all the Artillery and Amunitions that were therein: The Spaniards being already arrived to the Port of the ≈øaid Ro≈øes, with all things nece≈ø≈øary to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it.

div.head: Naples, June ‚Ä¢ . 1660.
div.p: Mr. Elpidio Beneditti, Cardinal Mazarines Agent, is gone from hence to Rome, being very well ≈øatisfied with the Vice-Roy, who pre≈øented him ≈øix brave Hor≈øes. The occa≈øion of his voyage was for the re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Prince of Monaco into all the Lands belonging to him in this Kingdome, according to the Treaty of Peace. Be≈øides the 2000. Italians, and 1000. Germans, lately ≈øent from hence into Spain, with abundance of Ammunitions and Provi≈øions: The Forces that are in the Milanez, being 5000. Foot, and 2000. Hor≈øe, are to be tran≈øported al≈øo thither in the Galleys of this Kingdome, to be imployed again≈øt Portugal. Cardinal Filomarini's goods have been ≈øeized on.

div.head: Rome, June 7. 1660.
div.p: The Cardinal Maldachini, formerly fallen into the Popes di≈øgrace, hath been recalled home by the mediation of Cardinal Antonio. But the Pope having chidden him very bitterly, when he went to ki≈øs his Toe, and make his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øions unto him; the Cardinal took it ≈øo much to heart, and was ≈øo highly di≈øplea≈øed at it, that he hath ≈øince withdrawn him≈øelf again from Rome.

div.head: Madrid, June 3. 1660.
div.p:
The Marquis of Manzera, ordinary Amba≈ø≈øadour of the Republick of Venice in this Court, hath been recalled, and is to di≈øcharge the ≈øame Fu ‚Ä¢ ction in the Court of France. The Spaniards are very much incen≈øed at the late inva≈øion made by the Portuguez upon the Spani≈øh Dominions, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
it is reported, that for to be revenged of it, they are re≈øolved to make incur≈øions into Portugal, and to make there as great havock as they can, for which end, orders have been given to fall on that Kingdome on all ≈øides. The Marquis of Vianes, Governour of Galicia, doth march that way with 8000 Foot, and 800 Hor≈øe; and the Governour of Camara marcheth another way with his Forces. We hear that tho≈øe of Lisbon are very much di≈øgu≈øted at the Queen of Portugal, and that the Council of the Chamber hath taken from her the management of the Affairs.

div.head: Turin, June 19. 1660.
div.p: The two Regiments of Foot that are ≈øent to the ≈øupply of the Venetians, were ≈øhipped away eight dayes ≈øince, upon the Po, but the Hor≈øe are not gone yet. The Governour of Milan hath demanded leave to rai≈øe ≈øome new Forces in Savoy. Two French Pirates bearing the Flag of Savoy, have lately ≈øeized upon a Grecian Ve≈ø≈øel coming from Algier to Mar≈øeille, which is intended here to be re≈øtored with all its lading. The King of France hath de≈øired that his Subjects ≈øhould pay no Toll at Villefranche, which not being granted, it hath cau≈øed ≈øome di≈øta≈øte; and we hear, that what comes from Dauphi ‚Ä¢ into Savoy, is ≈øeized there.

div.head: Riga in Lifland, 31 May 1660.
div.p: The News being come hither how Vice Admiral Ruyter had ≈øeized on to Suedi≈øh ≈øhips about Copenhagen; our Governour hath likewi≈øe made an Imbargo upon all the ≈øhips and goods belonging here to the Dutch, and doth threaten a Confi≈øcation of them, unle≈øs the Peace be ≈øuddenly concluded.

All things are preparing for the Dyet which is to be held at War≈øow, about the latter end of this month; but it is reported that the Nobility will not come thither, till after the King of Poland hath given them ≈øatisfaction upon their demands. The Great Duke of Mo≈øcovy is ≈øo much alarm'd by the peace concluded between Sueden and Poland, that he
hath ≈øent an Emba≈ø≈øadour to the King of Poland, to make ≈øome Propo≈øitions to him, much more advantageous then the former, with order to repair to War≈øow afore the opening of the Dyet, where the States, after they have ended the bu≈øine≈øs of the Ratification of peace, are particularly to take into con≈øideration how to expel the Mo≈øcovites out of Lithuania, it being re≈øolved to give the chief command of all the Forces to be imployed again≈øt them, unto General Czarnesky, and the Lieutenant≈øhip to the Waywode Sapiha. The Count Koningsmarck hath ≈øhipped away part of his Retinue for Lubeck, whither he is to go as ≈øoon as the news comes of the re≈øtauration of the Duke of Curland into his dominions.

Since the conclu≈øion of the Peace between the Kings of Sueden and Denmark, we enjoy here a perfect tranquility, although the Imperial forces be not yet removed from Macklenburgh and Pomerania, their Officers keeping ≈øuch an exact Di≈øcipline among them, that the Country is no way annoyed by them. A Suedi≈øh ≈øhip riding before Warnemunde to receive the Toll of all the ≈øhips coming into Ro≈øtock and going out from thence, was lately fired by a Thunderbolt that fell upon her: All the Souldiers that were aboard her were con≈øumed by the fire.

The 12 in≈øtant the young Prince, of whom the Dutche≈øs of Newburgh was brought to bed two days before, was Chri≈øtened at Du≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ldorp with great Ceremonies. The differences betwixt the City of Mun≈øter and the Bi≈øhop are ≈øo far from an accommodation, that at pre≈øent both the parties have no other thoughts but to put them≈øelves in po≈øture to right them≈øelves by the way of Arms. That Prelate who hopeth to have a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from ≈øeveral Princes of the Empire, being re≈øolved not to abate any thing of his pretentions, and the City being re≈øolved to venture all for the pre≈øervation of their Privile ‚Ä¢ ges.

div.head: Adverti≈øement of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p:
‚òû „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Na≈øorah, Seu Critica Divina, Or A Synoptital Directory on the Sacred Scriptures. The Fir≈øt part, Containing the ≈øeveral Canons of both Scriptures; Namely, of the Old and New Te≈øtament. (As the ≈øame are di≈øtingui≈øhed in the General Analy≈øis, at the begining of this Treati≈øe.) By Ferdinando Parkbur≈øt
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Sold by G. Bedel, and T. Gollins, at the Middle Temple-gate, Fleet≈øtreet, and James Mag ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, near the Piazza in Covent Garden.

There is a Book newly come forth in defence of Chri≈øt Je≈øus, Scriptures, Mini≈øtry and Mini≈øters, again≈øt ≈øome Principall Quakers. By Francis Duke of We≈øtmin≈øter. Sold by Miles Michael in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, the fir≈øt ≈øh ‚Ä¢ p on the right hand.

The Silent Soul, with Soveraign Antidotes again≈øt the mo≈øt Mi≈øerable Exegents, or a Chri≈øtian with an Olive Leaf in his mouth, when he is under the ≈øharpe≈øt Tryals and Troubles, the ≈øadd ‚Ä¢ ≈øt and da ‚Ä¢ ke≈øt Providences and Changes; and Publi≈øhed by Thomas Brook, Preacher of the Go≈øpel at Margaret Fi≈øh-≈øtreet hill.
App ‚Ä¢ or of Gold for young Men and Women, and a Crown of Glory for old Man and Weomen, or the happine≈øs of being good betimes. By the ≈øame Author.
A String of Pearl, or the be≈øt things re≈øerved till la≈øt; with a ≈øerious di≈øcour≈øe touching a well-grounded A≈ø≈øurance of Mans everla≈øting Happine≈øs and Ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs.
A Book of Short-Writing, the mo≈øt exact lineal, and ≈øpeedy, that hath been publi≈øhed. By Theophilus Metcalf.
That Sheltons Short-hand Book in Latine, very u≈øeful for all Schollers, and Foreign Nations, newly tran≈ølated and cut in B ‚Ä¢ a≈øs Plate.
All five ≈øold by John Hancock in Popes head Alley, the fir≈øt ≈øhop next Corn-hill.

‚òû We mu≈øt call upon you again for a Black Dog, between a Greyhound and a Spaniel, no white about him, onely a ≈øtreak on his Bre≈øt, and his Tayl a little bobbed. It is His Maje≈øties own Dog, and doubtle≈øs was ≈øtoln, for the Dog was not born nor bred in England, and would never for≈øake His Ma≈øter. Who≈øoever findes him may acquaint any at Whitehal, for the Dog was better known at Court, than tho≈øe who ≈øtole him. Will they never leave robbing His Maje≈øty? mu≈øt He not keep a Dog? This Dogs place (though better then ≈øome imagine) is the only place which no body offers to beg.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: ‚òû A Leather Portmantle lo≈øt at Sittingburn or Roche≈øter, when his Maje≈øty came thither, wherein was a Suit of Camolet Holland, with two little laces in a ≈øeam, eight pair of white Gloves, and a pair of Does leather; about twenty yards of ski ‚Ä¢ -colour'd Ribbon twelvepenny broad, and a whole piece of black Ribbon ten penny broad; a cloath lead coloured cloak, with ≈øtore of linnen; a pair of ≈øhooes, ≈ølippers, a Montero and other things; all which belong to a Gentleman (a near Servant to His Maje≈øty) who hath been too long Impri≈øoned and Seque≈øtred, to be now robbed when all men hope to enjoy their own. If any can give notice, they may leave word with Mr. Samuel Merne His Maje≈øties Book-binder, at his hou≈øe in Little Britain, and they ≈øhall be thankfully rewarded.

p.hi: A Black Mare 14 handful high, with a ≈øtar in her forehead, with a long tayl never dockt, five years old. Lo≈øt out of a piece of a G ‚Ä¢ ound near Cambden-hou≈øe, Kin≈øing ‚Ä¢ on: If any one can give notice of her to Mr. Richa ‚Ä¢ d Kellaways at the Ro≈øe in Knights-bridge, or to Mr. James Pierce at the White-Hea ‚Ä¢ t in Long-acre, they ≈øhall be well rewarded for their pains,

div.head: Whitehal Wedne≈øday the 27 of June.
div.p: This day the Maior of St. Albans, accompanied with Mr. Foxwi≈øt the Recorder, and ≈øome of the principal Burge≈ø≈øes his Brethren, as the Repre≈øentative of the ≈øaid Corporation, made their Humble Addre≈øs to His Maje≈øty, the Recorder making a ≈øhort and pithy Speech by way of Congratulation of his Maje≈øties happy Re≈øtauration to his Royal Throne; and a≈ø≈øurance of their Loyalty and Allegiance to his Maje≈øty: and pre≈øented him with a Re≈øignation of the Fee-Farm-rent purcha≈øed by the Corporation in His Maje≈øties ab≈øence, and the Arrears incurred in the mean time being a 100 l. in Gold, which His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed Graciou≈øly to accept, and to expre≈øs his kind acceptance thereof, and that the Corporation ≈øhould, as occa≈øion required, participate of his Royal Grace and Favour.

div.head: From Innerne≈øs, June 16.
div.p:
I have as I acquainted you in my la≈øt, made inquiry into the
bu≈øine≈øs of Capt. Roll, which was contradicted in ≈øome late Pamphlets, but upon di≈øcour≈øe with Sir James Smith and Mr. Calmady. I finde that the ≈øaid Capt. Roll was ≈øei≈øed for ≈øpeaking words, and that Mr. Calmady giving too much credit to him that brought the note, did in ha≈øte ≈øign it.

Wedne≈øday, Dr. Colladon, Deputy from the Commonwealth of Geneva, having pre≈øented unto His Maje≈øty the Letters of th ‚Ä¢ Lords Syndicks and Magi≈øtra ‚Ä¢ es, and of the Pa≈øtors and Profe≈ø≈øors of that place, congratulating His Maje≈øties happy Return and Re≈øtauration to his Kingdomes; And demanded in their Name of His Maje≈øty, the continuation of His Royal Favour and good Affection towards them. His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to return them thanks for their expre≈ø≈øion of ≈øo Cordial a re≈øpect, and to give to the ≈øaid Deputies a very gracious and acceptable An≈øwer upon his Demand.

His Maje≈øty having been plea≈øed to be≈øtow a Grant for the Degree and Honour of Baronet upon Nicholas Steward of Hartly Mawditt, in the County of Southampton‚ñ™ E≈øquire; A Patent pa≈ø≈øed under the Great Seal of England for conferring the ≈øaid Honour and Degree of Baronet upon the ≈øaid Sir Nicholas Steward accordingly.

div.head: Whitehal.
div.p: On Monday la≈øt Colonel Sir John Robin≈øon, Alderman of London, and a Member of this Parliament, was by his Maje≈øty made Lieutenant of the Tower of London, an action mo≈øt acceptable not only to the City and Parliament, but indeed to the whole Nation; the very pri≈øoners them≈øelves being glad of his company.

The Kingdome having for a long time, by rea≈øon of his Maje≈øties ab≈øence, been troubled with the Evil, great numbers have lately flocked for Cure. His Sacred Maje≈øty on Monday la≈øt touched 250 in the Banquetting Hou≈øe, among≈øt whom, when his Maje≈øty was delivering the Gold, one ≈øhuffled him≈øelf in, out of an hope of profit, which had not been ≈øtroak'd; but his Maje≈øty pre≈øently di≈øcovered him, ≈øaying, This man hath not yet been touched. His Maje≈øty
hath for the future appointed every Friday for the Cure, at which time 200. and no more are to be pre≈øented to him, who are fir≈øt to repair to Mr. Knight, His Maje≈øties Chyrurgion, living at the Cro≈øs-Guns in Ru≈ø≈øel ≈øtreet, Covent-Garden, over again≈øt the Ro≈øe Tavern, for their Tickets. That none might loo≈øe their labour, tis thought fit to make it known, that he will be at his hou≈øe every Wedne≈øday and Thur≈øday, from Two till Six of the Clock, to attend that ≈øervic ‚Ä¢ : And if any per≈øon of Quality ≈øhall ≈øend to him, he will wait on them at their lodgings upon notice given to him.
On Tue≈øday His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to be at Supper with the Lord Barcley, where he was very highly entertained.

His Maje≈øty hath been graciou≈øly plea≈øed, to make Sir William Compton, brother to the Earl of Nothampton, Ma≈øter of his Maje≈øties Ordnance; Col. William Legge, Lieutenant of the Ordnance; Per≈øons that have ≈øuffered with his Maje≈øty in all his troubles; and Major Francis Nicols Surveyor of his Ordnance‚ñ™ his faithfulne≈øs in adhering to his Excellency in all the≈øe late Changes.

The≈øe following were re≈øtored to their Offices, being formerly put out for ≈øerving his Maje≈øty, viz. Edward Sherborne to his place of Clerk to his Maje≈øties Ordnance, Mr. Mar≈øh to his place of Storekeeper, and Mr. Clark formerly Commi≈ø≈øary General in his late Maje≈øties Army, to his place of Clerk of the Deliveries.
His Maje≈øty conferred on Mr. Hore the Office of Comptroller of his Maje≈øties Mint.

That the Souldiery may ≈øee the affection that his Sacred Maje≈øty hath for the Army, he hath been plea≈øed to do them ≈øo much honour, as to take that Regiment that was lately Col. Unton Crooks, for his own, which is now ≈øtiled, The Royal Regiment: What the Names of the Officers are, you may ≈øee in the next.

His Highne≈øs the Duke of York, hath ≈øo far honoured the Regiment of the Lord Falconberg as to own it, which is now called, The Duke of Yorks Regiment, the Lord Falconberg and the Officers being ≈øtill continued.

div.head: From His Excellency Quarters at the Cock-pit.
div.p: His Excellency ha ‚Ä¢ h been plea≈øed, lately to change ≈øome Officers, and di≈øpo≈øe their commands to o ‚Ä¢ her ‚Ä¢ .
He hath given the command of the Troop late Captain Shermans, in the Lord Vi≈øcount Falklands Regiment, to Col. Henry Heylin.
The T ‚Ä¢ oop that was late Capt. Greenwoods in the ≈øame Regiment to Capt. Tho. Mo ‚Ä¢ ley.
The company late Major Waterhou≈øe's in Col. Daniels Regiment to Capt. Leonard Aizay.

His Ex ‚Ä¢ ellency hath likewi≈øe commi≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢ ned Major Adam Brown, Brother to Sir Ambro≈øe Brown, to be Major of Sir Anthony A≈øhley-Coopers Regiment, being about to confer a greater honor on Major Harley.

div.head: London.
div.p: The Lord Major and Aldermen of London, upon a Me≈ø≈øage from the Lord Chamberlain, delivered by Serjeant Charnock, concerning His Maje≈øties Reception, have ordered the ≈øtreets to be railed on one ≈øide; all the Livery-men will ≈øtand in their Formalities, with Banners and Streamers, di≈øtingui≈øhing each Company; on the other ≈øide the Guards. The Guards to wait on His Maje≈øty by eight in the morning at Whitehal, where the Lord Major, Aldermen, and City Officers in their Gowns, with about 600 of the ≈øeveral Companies, are to attend in their Velvet Coats and Chains, and Footmen following them; from whence they proceed in this order,

Fir≈øt, The Citizens in Velvet Coats and Chains, with Banners of di≈øtingui≈øhment; the Aldermen in their Gowns, next the Serjeants at Arms and Heralds, after them immediately before the Kings Coach, the Lord Major bare with the Sword; with Garter the King at Arms on the right hand, and His Maje≈øties Gentlemen U≈øher on the left; after which, His Maje≈øties Coach guarded on both ≈øides with His Royal Band of Pen≈øio ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s and Querries; after His Maje≈øties Coach, follow the Hou≈øe of Lords and Commons in their order; at Cheap≈øide they have appointed Pageants. Of this and other entertainment, you may expect more in the next.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: Phineas Paine that was lately committed upon mi≈øinformation given, that he was the per≈øon that executed His late Maje≈øty, is upon examination di≈øcharged.
London, Printed by J: Macock, and Tho. Newcomb, 1660.
